sn56.11:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.11:0.3.eng: Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
sn56.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

sn56.11:1.2.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn56.11:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the group of five mendicants:

sn56.11:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, these two extremes should not be cultivated by one who has gone forth.

sn56.11:2.3.pli: Yo cāyaṃ kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṃhito, yo cāyaṃ attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṃhito.
sn56.11:2.3.eng: Indulgence in sensual pleasures, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And indulgence in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.

sn56.11:2.4.pli: Ete kho, bhikkhave, ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn56.11:2.4.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One understood the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.11:3.1.pli: Katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati?
sn56.11:3.1.eng: And what is that middle way of practice?

sn56.11:3.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn56.11:3.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
sn56.11:3.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn56.11:3.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn56.11:3.4.eng: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.11:4.1.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ—
sn56.11:4.1.eng: Now this is the noble truth of suffering.

sn56.11:4.2.pli: jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, byādhipi dukkho, maraṇampi dukkhaṃ, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho, piyehi vippayogo dukkho, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ—saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
sn56.11:4.2.eng: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; illness is suffering; death is suffering; being coupled with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.

sn56.11:4.3.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ—
sn56.11:4.3.eng: Now this is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

sn56.11:4.4.pli: yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandirāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—
sn56.11:4.4.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,

sn56.11:4.5.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving to continue existence, and craving for nonexistence.

sn56.11:4.6.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ—
sn56.11:4.6.eng: Now this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

sn56.11:4.7.pli: yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo.
sn56.11:4.7.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

sn56.11:4.8.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ—
sn56.11:4.8.eng: Now this is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.11:4.9.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn56.11:4.10.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn56.11:5.1.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:5.1.eng: ‘This is the noble truth of suffering.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.

sn56.11:5.2.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pariññeyyan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe …pe… udapādi.
sn56.11:5.2.eng: ‘This noble truth of suffering should be completely understood.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:5.3.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pariññātan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:5.3.eng: ‘This noble truth of suffering has been completely understood.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:6.1.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:6.1.eng: ‘This is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:6.2.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pahātabban’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe …pe… udapādi.
sn56.11:6.2.eng: ‘This noble truth of the origin of suffering should be given up.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:6.3.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pahīnan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:6.3.eng: ‘This noble truth of the origin of suffering has been given up.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:7.1.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:7.1.eng: ‘This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:7.2.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ sacchikātabban’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe …pe… udapādi.
sn56.11:7.2.eng: ‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:7.3.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ sacchikatan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:7.3.eng: ‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering has been realized.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:8.1.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:8.1.eng: ‘This is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:8.2.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ bhāvetabban’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe …pe… udapādi.
sn56.11:8.2.eng: ‘This noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be developed.’ Such was the vision that arose in me …

sn56.11:8.3.pli: ‘Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ bhāvitan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn56.11:8.3.eng: ‘This noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering has been developed.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.

sn56.11:9.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca me, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu ariyasaccesu evaṃ tiparivaṭṭaṃ dvādasākāraṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ na suvisuddhaṃ ahosi, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn56.11:9.1.eng: As long as my true knowledge and vision about these four noble truths was not fully purified in these three rounds and twelve aspects, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn56.11:10.1.pli: Yato ca kho me, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu ariyasaccesu evaṃ tiparivaṭṭaṃ dvādasākāraṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ suvisuddhaṃ ahosi, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn56.11:10.1.eng: But when my true knowledge and vision about these four noble truths was fully purified in these three rounds and twelve aspects, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn56.11:10.2.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn56.11:10.3.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn56.11:10.3.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn56.11:10.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn56.11:10.5.pli: Attamanā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
sn56.11:10.5.eng: Satisfied, the group of five mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

sn56.11:11.1.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne āyasmato koṇḍaññassa virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
sn56.11:11.1.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in Venerable Koṇḍañña:

sn56.11:11.2.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

sn56.11:12.1.pli: Pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke bhummā devā saddamanussāvesuṃ:
sn56.11:12.1.eng: And when the Buddha rolled forth the Wheel of Dhamma, the earth gods raised the cry:

sn56.11:12.2.pli: “etaṃ bhagavatā bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
sn56.11:12.2.eng: “Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.”

sn56.11:12.3.pli: Bhummānaṃ devānaṃ saddaṃ sutvā cātumahārājikā devā saddamanussāvesuṃ:
sn56.11:12.3.eng: Hearing the cry of the earth gods, the gods of the four great kings …

sn56.11:12.4.pli: “etaṃ bhagavatā bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ, appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.

sn56.11:12.5.pli: Cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ saddaṃ sutvā tāvatiṃsā devā …pe…

sn56.11:12.8.eng: the gods who love to create …

sn56.11:12.9.eng: the gods who control what is created by others …

sn56.11:12.10.eng: the gods of the Divinity’s host raised the cry:

sn56.11:12.11.pli: “etaṃ bhagavatā bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
sn56.11:12.11.eng: “Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.”

sn56.11:13.1.pli: Itiha tena khaṇena tena layena tena muhuttena yāva brahmalokā saddo abbhuggacchi.
sn56.11:13.1.eng: And so at that moment, that second, that hour, the cry soared up to the realm of divinity.

sn56.11:13.2.pli: Ayañca dasasahassilokadhātu saṅkampi sampakampi sampavedhi, appamāṇo ca uḷāro obhāso loke pāturahosi atikkamma devānaṃ devānubhāvanti.
sn56.11:13.2.eng: And this ten-thousandfold galaxy shook and rocked and trembled. And an immeasurable, magnificent light appeared in the world, surpassing the glory of the gods.

sn56.11:14.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn56.11:14.1.eng: Then the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

sn56.11:14.2.pli: “aññāsi vata bho, koṇḍañño, aññāsi vata bho, koṇḍañño”ti.
sn56.11:14.2.eng: “Koṇḍañña has really understood! Koṇḍañña has really understood!”

sn56.11:14.3.pli: Iti hidaṃ āyasmato koṇḍaññassa “aññāsikoṇḍañño” tveva nāmaṃ ahosīti.
sn56.11:14.3.eng: And that’s how Venerable Koṇḍañña came to be known as “Koṇḍañña Who Understood”.

sn56.111-113:0.3.eng: Dying as Gods and Reborn as Humans

sn56.111-113:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye devā cutā manussesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye devā cutā niraye paccājāyanti …pe… tiracchānayoniyā paccājāyanti …pe… pettivisaye paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.111-113:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as gods and are reborn as humans are few, while those who die as gods and are reborn in hell, or the animal realm, or the ghost realm are many.”

sn56.126-128:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pettivisayā cutā manussesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye pettivisayā cutā niraye paccājāyanti …pe… tiracchānayoniyā paccājāyanti …pe… pettivisaye paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.126-128:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as ghosts and are reborn as humans are few, while those who die as ghosts and are reborn in hell, or the animal realm, or the ghost realm are many.”

sn56.129-130:0.3.eng: Dying as Ghosts and Reborn as Gods

sn56.129-130:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pettivisayā cutā devesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye pettivisayā cutā niraye paccājāyanti …pe…
sn56.129-130:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as ghosts and are reborn as gods are few, while those who die as ghosts and are reborn in hell are many.”

sn56.129-130:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pettivisayā cutā devesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye pettivisayā cutā tiracchānayoniyā paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.129-130:1.2.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as ghosts and are reborn as gods are few, while those who die as ghosts and are reborn in the animal realm are many.”

sn56.13:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.13:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.

sn56.13:1.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
sn56.13:1.3.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.13:2.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of suffering?

sn56.13:2.2.eng: You should say: ‘The five grasping aggregates’.

sn56.13:2.3.eng: That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn56.13:2.4.eng: This is called the noble truth of suffering.

sn56.13:3.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?

sn56.13:3.2.pli: Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandirāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—
sn56.13:3.2.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,

sn56.13:3.3.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

sn56.13:3.4.eng: This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

sn56.13:4.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?

sn56.13:4.2.pli: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo—
sn56.13:4.2.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

sn56.13:4.3.eng: This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

sn56.13:5.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?

sn56.13:5.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn56.13:5.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn56.13:5.4.pli: idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
sn56.13:5.4.eng: This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.13:5.5.eng: These are the four noble truths.

sn56.13:6.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.13:6.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.131:0.3.eng: Dying as Ghosts and Reborn as Ghosts

sn56.131:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pettivisayā cutā devesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye pettivisayā cutā pettivisaye paccājāyanti.
sn56.131:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as ghosts and are reborn as gods are few, while those who die as ghosts and are reborn in the ghost realm are many.

sn56.131:1.3.eng: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.

sn56.131:1.5.pli: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa.
sn56.131:1.5.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.131:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.131:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation to understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.”

sn56.131:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn56.131:3.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
sn56.131:3.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

sn56.131:4.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the Truths, the twelfth section.

sn56.14:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.14:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.

sn56.14:1.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
sn56.14:1.3.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.14:2.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of suffering?

sn56.14:2.2.eng: You should say: ‘The six interior sense fields’.

sn56.14:2.4.eng: The sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn56.14:2.5.eng: This is called the noble truth of suffering. …”

sn56.14:3.2.pli: Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandirāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—kāmataṇhā, bhavataṇhā, vibhavataṇhā—

sn56.14:4.2.pli: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo—

sn56.14:5.4.pli: idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.

sn56.14:6.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.

sn56.15:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.15:1.1.pli: “Dhāretha no tumhe, bhikkhave, mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti?
sn56.15:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, do you remember the four noble truths that I taught?”

sn56.15:1.2.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn56.15:1.2.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha:

sn56.15:1.3.pli: “ahaṃ kho, bhante, dhāremi bhagavatā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti.

sn56.15:1.4.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāresi mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti?

sn56.15:1.5.pli: “Dukkhaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ dhāremi;
sn56.15:1.5.eng: “Sir, I remember that suffering is the first noble truth you’ve taught;

sn56.15:1.6.pli: dukkhasamudayaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dutiyaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ dhāremi;
sn56.15:1.6.eng: the origin of suffering is the second;

sn56.15:1.7.pli: dukkhanirodhaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā tatiyaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ dhāremi;
sn56.15:1.7.eng: the cessation of suffering is the third;

sn56.15:1.8.pli: dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ dhāremi.
sn56.15:1.8.eng: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is the fourth.

sn56.15:1.9.pli: Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, dhāremi bhagavatā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti.
sn56.15:1.9.eng: That’s how I remember the four noble truths as you’ve taught them.”

sn56.15:2.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāresi mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānīti.
sn56.15:2.2.eng: It’s good that you remember the four noble truths as I’ve taught them.

sn56.15:2.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ kho, bhikkhu, mayā paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ, tathā naṃ dhārehi;
sn56.15:2.3.eng: Suffering is the first noble truth I’ve taught, and that’s how you should remember it.

sn56.15:2.4.pli: dukkhasamudayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, mayā dutiyaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ, tathā naṃ dhārehi;
sn56.15:2.4.eng: The origin of suffering is the second;

sn56.15:2.5.pli: dukkhanirodhaṃ kho, bhikkhu, mayā tatiyaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ, tathā naṃ dhārehi;
sn56.15:2.5.eng: the cessation of suffering is the third;

sn56.15:2.6.pli: dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā kho, bhikkhu, mayā catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ, tathā naṃ dhārehi.
sn56.15:2.6.eng: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is the fourth.

sn56.15:2.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, dhārehi mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānīti.
sn56.15:2.7.eng: That’s how you should remember the four noble truths as I’ve taught them.

sn56.15:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhu, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.15:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
